Package com.bakdata.dedupe.similarity

Class CommonSimilarityMeasures

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.bakdata.dedupe.similarity.CommonSimilarityMeasures
  • public final class CommonSimilarityMeasures
extends java.lang.Object
    A utility class that offers factory methods for common similarity measures. Usually, these methods are included through static imports.

    For new similarity measure, please open an issue or PR on Github }.

    See Also:
    CommonTransformations

      • jaccard

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.Collection<? extends E>> @NonNull SetSimilarityMeasure<C,​E> jaccard()
        Treats the input collections as sets (removing duplicate elements) and calculates the size of the intersection over the size of the union.

        Returns:
        the Jaccard set similarity.

      • levenshtein

        @NonNull
public static <T extends java.lang.CharSequence> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> levenshtein()
        Returns the Levenshtein similarity measure. It is often referred to as edit-distance, but it is actually the most known instance of edit distance.

        The similarity is calculated by normalizing the number of edits over the maximum input length.

        Note that Levenshtein distance is really slow, but can be tremulously sped up by using a threshold (e.g., SimilarityMeasure.cutoff(double) or SimilarityMeasure.scaleWithThreshold(double)).

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Returns:
        the Levenshtein distance.

public static <T extends java.lang.CharSequence> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> jaroWinkler()

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Returns:
        the Jaro-Winkler similarity.

      • toSimilarity

        @NonNull
public static <T extends java.lang.CharSequence,​R extends java.lang.Number> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> toSimilarity​(@NonNull
                                                                                                                             @NonNull org.apache.commons.text.similarity.EditDistance<R> editDistance)
        Used to translate EditDistance of apache commons-text into a similarity score by using the formula 1 - dist / maxDist where maxDist is the maximum length of the input strings.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Returns:
        the given edit distance translated into a SimilarityMeasure.

      • stableMatching

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.Collection<? extends E>> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<C> stableMatching​(SimilarityMeasure<E> pairMeasure)
        Will find the (weakly) stable matches between the left and the right side with a given pair similarity measure and calculate the average similarity between the stable pairs.

        A pair (A, B) is (weakly) stable if neither A or B have another element C, such that A (or B) prefer C over their current partner and that C also prefers the element of his current partner.

        The average similarity is normalized over the maximum number of elements in left or right, such that superfluous partners degrade the overall similarity.

        Stable matching prefers the left side over the right side.

        Type Parameters:
        E - the element type.
        C - the collection type.
        Parameters:
        pairMeasure - the similarity measure to use to calculate the preferences and the overall similarity.
        Returns:
        a stable matching similarity.
        See Also:
        Stable marriage on Wikipedia

      • mongeElkan

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.Collection<? extends E>> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<C> mongeElkan​(SimilarityMeasure<E> pairMeasure)
        Monge-Elkan is a simple list-based similarity measure, where elements from the left are matched with elements from the right with the highest similarity within a certain index range.

        It is simple in the regard that the same element on the right side can be matched multiple times to left elements.

        For non-repeating matching, consider matching(BipartiteMatcher, SimilarityMeasure).

        However, it is comparably fast, as only the similarities within the neighborhood are calculated. For a larger neighborhood, the matching approach is usually preferable.

        Monge-Elkan prefers the left side over the right side.

        Note that Monge-Elkan distance can be well sped up by using a threshold (e.g., SimilarityMeasure.cutoff(double) or SimilarityMeasure.scaleWithThreshold(double)).

        Type Parameters:
        E - the element type.
        C - the collection type.
        Parameters:
        pairMeasure - the similarity measure to use to calculate the preferences and the overall similarity.
        Returns:
        the Monge-Elkan list-based similarity.

      • matching

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.Collection<? extends E>> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<C> matching​(BipartiteMatcher<E> matcher,
                                                                                                           SimilarityMeasure<? super E> pairMeasure)
        Uses the given pair SimilarityMeasure to calculate a preference matrix and uses the BipartiteMatcher to find the best matching entries. The best matches and their similarity are used to calculate the overall similarity.

        The average similarity is normalized over the maximum number of elements in left or right, such that superfluous partners degrade the overall similarity.

        Type Parameters:
        E - the element type.
        C - the collection type.
        Parameters:
        pairMeasure - the similarity measure to use to calculate the preferences and the overall similarity.
        Returns:
        a matching similarity measure.

      • cosine

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.Collection<? extends E>> @NonNull CollectionSimilarityMeasure<C,​E> cosine()
        Calculates the cosine similarity measure over two bags of elements.

        It first calculates the histograms of the two bags, interprets them as count vectors, and computes the cosine similarity.

        This measure is suited for medium to long texts.

        Type Parameters:
        E - the element type.
        C - the collection type.
        Returns:
        the cosine similarity.

      • mongeElkan

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.Collection<? extends E>> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<C> mongeElkan​(SimilarityMeasure<E> pairMeasure,
                                                                                                             int maxPositionDiff)
        Monge-Elkan is a simple list-based similarity measure, where elements from the left are matched with elements from the right with the highest similarity within a certain index range.

        It is simple in the regard that the same element on the right side can be matched multiple times to left elements.

        For non-repeating matching, consider matching(BipartiteMatcher, SimilarityMeasure).

        However, it is comparably fast, as only the similarities within the neighborhood are calculated. For a larger neighborhood, the matching approach is usually preferable.

        Monge-Elkan prefers the left side over the right side.

        Note that Monge-Elkan distance can be well sped up by using a threshold (e.g., SimilarityMeasure.cutoff(double) or SimilarityMeasure.scaleWithThreshold(double)).

        Type Parameters:
        E - the element type.
        C - the collection type.
        Parameters:
        pairMeasure - the similarity measure to use to calculate the preferences and the overall similarity.
        maxPositionDiff - the maximum index difference of the left list item and the right list item.
        Returns:
        the Monge-Elkan list-based similarity.

      • negate

        @NonNull
public static <T> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> negate​(SimilarityMeasure<T> measure)
        Swaps the lower and upper bound, such that equal pairs have a similarity of 0 and unequal pairs of 1.

        In particular, the returned similarity is 1 - this.sim.

        Note that this method offers somewhat better type inference than SimilarityMeasure.negate().

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Parameters:
        measure - the measure to negate.
        Returns:
        a negated similarity measure.

      • positionWise

        @NonNull
public static <E,​C extends java.util.List<? extends E>> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<C> positionWise​(SimilarityMeasure<E> pairMeasure)
        Performs a simple one to one comparison of elements in two lists based on their index.
        Type Parameters:
        E - the element type.
        C - the collection type.
        Parameters:
        pairMeasure - the similarity measure to use to calculate the overall similarity.
        Returns:
        a position-wise comparing, list-based similarity measure.

@NonNull
public static <T> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> max​(SimilarityMeasure<? super T>... measures)
        Returns the largest similarity of the given similarity measures.

        If all of the similarities are SimilarityMeasure.unknown(), then the result is also unknown.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Parameters:
        measures - the non-empty list of similarity measures.
        Returns:
        the largest similarity of the given similarity measures.

      • scaledDifference

        @NonNull
public static <T extends java.time.temporal.Temporal> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> scaledDifference​(int maxDiff,
                                                                                                     java.time.temporal.TemporalUnit unit)
        Calculates the difference between the left and right Temporal and compares the absolute difference to maxDiff.

        A difference of 0 will result in a similarity of 1 and a difference at or over maxDiff will result in a similarity of 0. Intermediate values will be linearly scaled.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Parameters:
        maxDiff - the maximum difference (exclusive) to yield a positive similarity.
        unit - the time unit of maxDiff.
        Returns:
        the scaled difference in [0; maxDiff) resulting in (0; 1] or 0 otherwise.

      • scaledDifference

        @NonNull
public static <T extends java.lang.Number> @NonNull SimilarityMeasure<T> scaledDifference​(@NonNull
                                                                                          T maxDiff)
        Calculates the difference between the left and right number and compares the absolute difference to maxDiff.

        A difference of 0 will result in a similarity of 1 and a difference at or over maxDiff will result in a similarity of 0. Intermediate values will be linearly scaled.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Parameters:
        maxDiff - the maximum difference (exclusive) to yield a positive similarity.
        Returns:
        the scaled difference in [0; maxDiff) resulting in (0; 1] or 0 otherwise.

      • weightedAggregation

        @NonNull
public static <T> @NonNull WeightedAggregatingSimilarityMeasure.WeightedAggregatingSimilarityMeasureBuilder<T> weightedAggregation​(java.util.function.ToDoubleFunction<java.util.stream.Stream<WeightedAggregatingSimilarityMeasure.WeightedValue>> aggregator)
        Starts the creation of a weighted aggregation of multiple SimilarityMeasures.

        SimilarityMeasure.unknown() values are not passed to the aggregation function.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Parameters:
        aggregator - the aggregation function to apply on the similarity values. Premature termination encouraged.
        Returns:
        a builder for the weighted aggregation.

      • weightedAverage

        @NonNull
public static <T> @NonNull WeightedAggregatingSimilarityMeasure.WeightedAggregatingSimilarityMeasureBuilder<T> weightedAverage()
        Starts the creation of a weighted average of multiple SimilarityMeasures.

        SimilarityMeasure.unknown() values to not contribute to the average at all.

        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the record.
        Returns:
        a builder for the weighted aggregation.
